title: Chhau
hero_image_alt: Chhau dancers in masks performing martial moves
short_description: A semi-classical form spanning Odisha, Bengal, and Jharkhand, combining martial arts and storytelling.
long_description:
Chhau is a major tradition of eastern India. It is a unique form of masked dance (in the Purulia and Seraikella styles) that uses vigorous martial movements to enact stories from epics. The Mayurbhanj style of Odisha uses no masks. 

The dance is performed during the Chaitra Parva festival and depicts themes from the Ramayana and Mahabharata. The movements are inspired by combat techniques (Parikhanda) and animal gaits (Chalis). It involves high leaps, somersaults, and rapid footwork.
costume_and_makeup: Purulia and Seraikella styles use elaborate clay/paper-mache masks. Mayurbhanj uses none. Costumes are colorful pyjamas.
key_traditions: Performed at night in open fields

top_places.title: Purulia, West Bengal

practical_info.audience_tips: It is physically intense. The masks in Purulia Chhau are works of art.
